docs.lead_paragraph: Men who conceive with a woman to whom they are not married should pay pregnancy-support alimony, or “preglimony.”
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by professor Shari Motro argues that parental responsibility begins at conception, and that men who conceive with a woman to whom they are not married should pay pregnancy-support alimony; notes that advances in prenatal blood tests could make the enforcement of such a rule safe.
docs.snippet: Men who conceive with a woman to whom they are not married should pay pregnancy-support alimony, or “preglimony.”

docs.lead_paragraph: There are many ways for pregnant women to stay fit, especially in New York City.

headline.seo: Staying Fit While Pregnant in New York

docs.abstract: Many New York City gyms accommodate pregnant women and some even offer exercise classes specifically for prenatal fitness.
docs.snippet: There are many ways for pregnant women to stay fit, especially in New York City.

docs.lead_paragraph: Zoos are trying to mate captive cheetahs and many other animals as so-called insurance populations before their situation in the wild becomes untenable.

headline.seo: Matchmaking at Zoos Is Rising for Threatened Species
headline.main: Date Night at the Zoo, if Rare Species Play Along
headline.print_headline: Date Night at the Zoo, if Rare Species Play Along

docs.abstract: Zoos are trying to mate captive cheetahs and about 160 other endangered species as so-called insurance populations before their situation in the wild becomes untenable; 83 percent of those species in North American zoos are not meeting the targets set for maintaining their genetic diversity (Series: The Animal Lifeboat).
docs.snippet: Zoos are trying to mate captive cheetahs and many other animals as so-called insurance populations before their situation in the wild becomes untenable.

docs.lead_paragraph: This week: barbecue hazards, colon cancer and pregnancy rates. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
docs.snippet: This week: barbecue hazards, colon cancer and pregnancy rates. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

docs.lead_paragraph: The OraQuick test, which uses a mouth swab and gives results in 20 to 40 minutes, is the first method for Americans to learn in the privacy of their own homes whether they are infected.

headline.seo: OraQuick At-Home H.I.V. Test Wins F.D.A. Approval
headline.main: Rapid H.I.V. Home Test Wins Federal Approval
headline.print_headline: F.D.A. Approves Rapid H.I.V. Test For Use At Home

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration, following decades of controversy, approves an easy-to-use, home HIV test; OraQuick test, manufactured by OraSure Technologies, uses a mouth swab and gives results in 20 to 50 minutes; AIDS researchers hail approval as a positive step forward in combating the spread of the disease.
docs.snippet: The OraQuick test, which uses a mouth swab and gives results in 20 to 40 minutes, is the first method for Americans to learn in the privacy of their own homes whether they are infected.

docs.lead_paragraph: A batch of new Travel Channel shows, from “Xtreme Waterparks” to “Insane Coaster Wars,” seems devised to annoy the summer couch potato.

headline.seo: Travel Channel’s ‘Xtreme Waterparks’ and ‘Insane Coaster Wars’
headline.main: Vacations To Steam All Couch Potatoes
headline.print_headline: Vacations To Steam All Couch Potatoes

docs.abstract: Neil Genzlinger asserts that the Travel Channel's summer lineup of extreme vacation shows is designed to ridicule people who are spending their vacations at home; jokingly suggests some new programs that would glorify the staycation.
docs.snippet: A batch of new Travel Channel shows, from “Xtreme Waterparks” to “Insane Coaster Wars,” seems devised to annoy the summer couch potato.

headline.main: Tuesday Reading: High-Protein Diet Linked to Heart Risks

docs.abstract: A high-protein diet is linked to heart risks, women seek an over-the-counter fix for libido, finding a missing Nook book and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
docs.snippet: A high-protein diet is linked to heart risks, women seek an over-the-counter fix for libido, finding a missing Nook book and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge agreed with arguments that a new state law was motivated by politics, not science. He temporarily blocked enforcement to close the clinic pending a hearing in 11 days.

headline.main: Mississippi’s Lone Abortion Clinic, Given Temporary Reprieve, Fields Rush of Calls
headline.print_headline: Mississippi’s Lone Abortion Clinic, Given Temporary Reprieve, Fields Rush of Calls

docs.abstract: Jackson Women's Health Organization, Mississippi abortion clinic scheduled to be shut down for non-compliance with new state law requiring doctors to be obstetrician-gynecologists at local hospitals, remains open after Judge Daniel P Jordan III of Federal District Court temporarily blocks enforcement; clinic, which is the state's only abortion provider, receives rush of calls from women seeking abortions before next round of battle in the courts.
docs.snippet: A federal judge agreed with arguments that a new state law was motivated by politics, not science. He temporarily blocked enforcement to close the clinic pending a hearing in 11 days.

docs.lead_paragraph: In her new book, Gail Collins focuses on Texas’s staggering inequality, casual embrace of crony capitalism and creaky educational pipeline. But her concern is that the state itself is everyone’s problem.

headline.main: Everything There Is Big, Stereotypes Included
headline.print_headline: Everything There Is Big, Stereotypes Included

docs.abstract: Erica Grieder reviews book As Texas Goes...How the Lone Star State Hijacked the American Agenda by Gail Collins.
docs.snippet: In her new book, Gail Collins focuses on Texas’s staggering inequality, casual embrace of crony capitalism and creaky educational pipeline. But her concern is that the state itself is everyone’s problem.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a study, young adults in Sweden who were born before 32 weeks of gestation had significantly higher rates of schizophrenia or delusional disorders, depression and bipolar illness.

headline.seo: Premature Birth May Raise Risk for Mental Illness, Study Reports
headline.main: Early Birth May Pose Higher Risk to the Mind
headline.print_headline: Early Birth May Pose Higher Risk To the Mind

docs.abstract: Dr Chiara Nosarti study in the Archives of General Psychiatry shows that premature birth may increase the risk for serious mental illness in adolescence and young adulthood.
docs.snippet: In a study, young adults in Sweden who were born before 32 weeks of gestation had significantly higher rates of schizophrenia or delusional disorders, depression and bipolar illness.
